Situation1: They are expected to be present at a family dinner or small gathering.
Expectation2: Communicate with clients and vendors regarding financial matters.
Situation2: A vendor sent a standard automated confirmation of a recent payment, to which a formal reply should be sent.
Story: I glanced at my phone, the group chat with my siblings lighting up with reminders about tonight’s family dinner. Mom had been planning it for weeks, and everyone expected me to be there, laughing and sharing stories over her famous lasagna. But as I was about to leave the office, an email notification popped up—our vendor had sent a payment confirmation, and protocol required a formal reply before the end of the business day. My manager had emphasized the importance of timely communication, especially with this vendor, and I knew a delay could reflect poorly on our firm. I stared at the screen, feeling the weight of both worlds pressing in. My family would be disappointed if I was late or distracted, but my professional reputation was on the line if I didn’t respond promptly. My heart pounded as I tried to decide which expectation to meet, torn between being the reliable sibling and the responsible accountant.
